lines.gurmukhi: sill suBwv dyKY borq n kwstih lwh ghY khY ApnoeI pRiqpwirE hY
lines.transliteration_english: Salil Soubhaav Daykhai Borat N Kaasatahi , Laah Gahai Kahai Apanoee Pratipaariao Hai ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Look at water, the nature of it never drowns wood in it. It regards the wood as his own having brought it up by irrigating it and thus keeps the shame of this relationship.

lines.gurmukhi: jugvq kwst irdMqir bYsMqrih bYsMqr AMqir lY kwsit pRjwirE hY
lines.transliteration_english: Jougavat Kaasat Ridantari Baisantarahi , Baisantar Antari Lai Kaasati Prajaariao Hai ?

Shabad OS B.translation: Wood keeps fire in it latently but taking the wood in itself the fire burns it (wood) to ashes.

lines.gurmukhi: Agrih jl boir kwFY bwfY mol qw ko pwvk pRdgD kY AiDk AautwirE hY
lines.transliteration_english: Agarahi Jal Bori Kaaddhai Baadai Mol Taa Ko , Paavak Pradagadh Kai Adhik Aoutaariao Hai ?

Shabad OS B.translation: The wood of Gularia Agalocha (Agar) resurfaces in water after sinking for sometime. This sinking increases the value of the wood. For burning it well in fire, it is boiled in water.

lines.gurmukhi: qaU qw ko ruDru cuie coAw hoie sll iml Aaugnih gun mwnY ibrdu bIcwirE hY ]425]
lines.transliteration_english: Taoo Taa Ko Rudharu Chui Choaa Hoi Salal Mila , Aouganahi Goun Maanai Biradu Beechaariao Hai ?425?

Shabad OS B.translation: Then its essence mixes well in water that becomes sweet smelling. For extracting the essence of the wood, the water has to bear the heat of the fire. But for its calm and tolerant nature, water changes its demerits into merits and thus fulfils its duties
